title: Why did the Soviet Union exist in the first place even when Lenin spoke of self-determination for all people and his opposition to the ethnic chauvinism of 'Greater Russia'? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Great Russian” means the ethnicity we usually call “Russian” as opposed to “White Russian” (Belarusian) and “Little Russian” (Ukrainian). So Great Russian chauvinism does not mean chauvinistic aspirations to build a Greater Russia, but Russian ethnic chauvinism towards other ethnicities. The Soviet Union, formed in 1922 after the complex chaos of the Civil War, did reflect the Leninist policy of self-determination for peoples. There was widespread de-Russification in the republics: they really were supposed to be republics of the main indigenous ethnicities where local languages and cultures were lifted up from previous suppression. This soon turned into murderous accusations of “bourgeois nationalism” under Stalin and the republics, as they were meant to be, were history in the “Steel monster’s” totalitarian state.

Because it had violence potential. Every state is basically a gang of organized crime which has its own territory and sovereign monopoly of violence there. USSR had enough violence potential to crush all competitors and its leaders were ruthless enough to keep it together and coerce monopoly of violence over its subjects on its territory. USSR was basically a state which was in war against its own citizens.
